habitat_description:
This species is only found in the Jemez Mountains found in Sandoval, Los Alamos, Rio Arriba counties in north-central New Mexico (Degenhardt et al. 1996; Stebbins 2003). This species is only described to occur in the high elevation of the mountains near the caldera of the Valle Grande of the Jemez Mountains (Degenhardt et al. 1996; Petranka 1998). Stebbins (2003) reports an elevational range of 2190 to 2800 meters.
The habitat of this species includes coniferous forests that are dominated by blue spruce, Douglas fir, Engelman spruce, ponderosa pine, aspen, white fir, New Mexico locust, oceanspray, and Rocky Mountain maple (Degenhardt et al. 1996). Individuals are usually found under decaying logs, under rocks, flat areas, and steep slopes (Degenhardt et al. 1996). Egg deposition sites are presumed to include deeply fractured interstices of metamorphic subterranean rock; soils such as pumice and tuft are not suitable. This habitat is vulnerable to soil compaction by the use of heavy logging machinery.


Associated with blue spruce, Douglas fir, Engelman spruce, ponderosa pine, aspen, white fir, New Mexico locust, oceanspray, and Rocky Mountain maple (Degenhardt et al. 1996).
